Some of you are pointing out his politics. This does not speak to my point. He is a good and hardworking reporter - within a domain that he has defined as a successful professional. 

I am questioning the forces that reward him, and which determine what coverage we receive.

1119986505764757504.text:
Finally, market forces. This is on us, the readers. We are drawn to horserace commentary. 

Framing the question of impeachment in terms of the health of our democracy? Important, but loses many. 

Who's up, who's down? Easy to digest, doesn't require expertise. So we consume.

1119985986790989824.text:
Another factor: reporters know how to report - but don't have depth knowledge. How many J.D. holders work for the @nytimes national desk? So they can't evaluate OLC stance on criminal prosecutions, definition of obstruction and so on.

But they *can* ask what someone else thinks.

1119985299927588865.text:
Like all professionals, national reporters may look to one another to decide what to do. And the @nytimes is a leader.

A few weeds:

Districts tend to distribute with an SD about +/-15 points above or below national average. (This generates the seats-votes curve known to political scientists.)

Therefore half of districts will be more extreme than +/-10 points from nat'l average.

1104409789793210368.text:
General expectation for single-member-districts: at least half of districts tend to be party-dominated. In these cases, only the primary matters.

If 1 in 5 primaries elects an outlier candidate, that's about 40 well-left-of Democrats D's,  40 well-right-of-Republicans R's. https://twitter.com/mattyglesias/status/1104405570193375232 …

1099479370744377345.text: The commission takes the governor out of the process. Good timing, that, considering the governor's current political weakness.

1099479026421374977.text: The amendment also allows the qualifications to be a commissioner to be set in general law by the General Assembly. So there's yet a chance to rule out some of the worst forms of nepotism.

1099478803515092992.text:
The citizen commissioners are drawn from a pool that is nominated by General Assembly leaders. That leaves open a problem of self-dealing. 

But...from that pool, the 8 commissioners are selected by a committee of retired judges. And public attention could help reduce the risk.

1099478012469407744.text:
This is a process-oriented reform. It mostly doesn't use formulas about partisan fairness or competitive districts to achieve balance. 

An exception: "Districts shall provide...opportunities for racial and ethnic communities to elect candidates of their choice." That's good!

1096612944920698882.text:
Generally, it is possible for state courts to provide for *more* rights than federal courts do. So a new state protection can be reconciled with a wide range of possible actions by SCOTUS.

We give dozens of examples where states used their own law/constitution to overturn a map.

1096611858566598656.text: Their logic is built upon the concepts of freedom of association and equal protection. These provisions are found in state constitutions across the nation. As long as it doesn't conflict with federal law, a state court-based ruling is **not subject to SCOTUS review**.

1096611209351180288.text: In "Laboratories of Democracy Reform: State Constitutions and Partisan Gerrymandering" we argue that Chief Justice Roberts and Justice Kagan have built a strong intellectual framework. Even if they themselves don't use it, it's available for state courts. https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3335622 …

1089397168878874625.text: We have the Electoral College so that slaveowners could vote their slaves. In the Presidential election of 1792, there were 132 electoral votes, with 53 EV in states with significant slave populations (GA/MD/NC/SC/VA). About 11 EV arose from the slave population.

1089393157018697728.text: House-type electors were (and are) proportional to population. But how to count slaves? Under the logic of slavery, it would not be fitting for them to vote. But their owners wanted the power of their numbers. So they counted for three-fifths of a person each.

1089393044628082688.text:
The Electoral College was part of the same compromise that led to the apportionment of the House and Senate. (Recall that each state gets electors = members of House and Senate combined.) 

A major, major driving force was slavery.
